newsitem.title: USA: Blue-chip stocks slip on fresh interest rates fears.
newsitem.headline: Blue-chip stocks slip on fresh interest rates fears.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks meandered in a narrow trading Tuesday amid a resurgence of interest rate anxieties.
At 1 p.m. EST, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 11.54 points at 7,067.85, one day after soaring 79 points to its 14th record of the year.
In the broader market, declining issues led advances by 13-9 on moderate volume of 267 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. The Nasdaq composite index was off 2.66 points to 1,320.06.
"Last week's worries about Federal Reserve policy have resurfaced," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment strategist at First Albany Corp.
In the bond market, the 30-year Treasury bond was off a half point, which raised its yield to 6.86 percent from Monday's close of 6.82 percent.
Bonds took their cue from an uptick in fourth quarter productivity and labour costs data.

The Labour Department said productivity rose by 1.1 percent in the fourth quarter vs. a 2.2 percent rise the previous quarter, while unit labour costs rose 2.5 percent after a 1.4 percent increase in the third quarter.
"Most investors concluded Friday that there was no upward pressure on wages and therefore the Fed would not raise rates," Johnson said.

"This report has rekindled worries and said to the bond and stock markets that there is still a chance the Fed will launch its pre-emptive strike at the March 25 or May 20 meeting of the FOMC (the Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee)," he said.
Johnson said, "The worry is that rising unit labour costs will lead to price increases as businesses try to preserve margins. That has traditionally been the case."
He said that optimism in the bond market was on the slide, and this has taken the gusto out of the stock market rally.
Bill Meehan, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said the stock market was bearing up adequately given the decline in bonds and the subsequent rise in the long-term yield.
"The market continues to amaze with its ability to shrug off bond yields which are creeping higher," he said.
Meehan said that there was nervousness among bond market traders ahead of Thursday's report on February retail sales and Friday's February wholesale price report.
"If we get through the numbers okay we could see a relief rally in the bond market," he said.

The 30-stock Dow Jones index drew what strength it had primarily from International Business Machines Corp., which rose 2-7/8 to 148-7/8, Boeing Co. up 1-7/8 at 107-3/4, and Procter & Gamble, which was up 1-1/4 at 126.
IBM, Oracle Corp., Sun Microsystems Inc. and Netscape Communications Corp. said they were collaborating on setting standards for network computing.

The companies said the standards that result from efforts would allow software developers to build diverse programmes to connect clients and servers through corporate networks, business-to-business networks and the Internet.
Oracle was up 3/8 at 36-3/8 and Sun Micro rose 5/8 to 31-7/8. Netscape was down 1-3/4 at 27-7/8.
